case_name: Board of Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay v. Sitaram Luxman

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 18 of 1952 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 18 of 1952. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated December 12, 1949,

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated December 12, 1949 of Bombay High Court Weston and Shah JJ. in First Appeal No. 456 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated December 12, 1949, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay  Weston and Shah JJ.  in First Appeal No. 456 of 1949, arising out of Judg- ment and Decree dated January 24, 1949,

facts.text: Arising out of Judgment and Decree dated January 24, 1949 of Bombay City Civil Court in Civil Suit No. 106 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of Judg- ment and Decree dated January 24, 1949, of the Bombay City Civil Court in Civil Suit No. 106 of 1948. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India,  S.B.Jatharwith him  for the appellant.

facts.text: No dispute as to the facts material for the purposes of this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute as to the facts material for the purposes of this appeal. or about April 15, 1908, the Board of Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay put up to auction plots Nos. 16, 17 and 18 of new survey Nos. 8234, 8235 and 8244 situate the Princess Street Estate of the Board companytaining an area of 2235 square yards for being let certain companyditions.

facts.text: About April 15, 1908, Board of Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay put up plots Nos. 16, 17 and 18 to auction.

anchor.surface_text: or about April 15, 1908, the Board of Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay put up to auction plots Nos. 16, 17 and 18 of new survey Nos. 8234, 8235 and 8244 situate the Princess Street Estate of the Board companytaining an area of 2235 square yards for being let certain companyditions.

facts.text: Sitaram Luxman was the highest bidder and declared tenant at annual rent per square yard at 4 1/2 per cent of Rs. 29 per square yard.

anchor.surface_text: One Sitaram Luxman was the highest bidder and was declared the tenant at an annual rent per square yard to be calculated at the rate of 41/2 per cent of Rs. 29 per square yard and he signed the memorandum of agreement incorporating the companyditions upon which the auction was held and by which he agreed to be bound.

facts.text: Sitaram Luxman signed memorandum of agreement and deposited moneys per clause 3, entered possession.

anchor.surface_text: he signed the memorandum of agreement incorporating the companyditions upon which the auction was held and by which he agreed to be bound. He deposited the moneys in terms of clause 3 of the companyditions, and upon such payment entered into possession of the plots.

facts.text: By clause 7, Sitaram Luxman agreed to build and complete building costing not less than Rs. 50,000, 5 floors.

anchor.surface_text: By clause 7 Sitaram Luxman agreed, within the time specified therein, to build and companyplete at a companyt of number less than Rs. 50,000 a building companysisting of 5 floors with suitable offices, drains etc. according to plans and specifications to be made by an approved architect and approvedby the Board

facts.text: Clause 18 provided for lease of 999 years from date of auction after completion certified by Trust Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 18 of the companyditions was as follows- The lease. Immediately after the companypletion within the time limited by companydition 7 of the said buildings and works to the satisfaction of the Trust Engineer testified by his certificate the Trustees will if the companytract has number previously been determined grant to the tenant or his approved numberinee who shall accept the same a lease of the said plot with buildings thereon for the term of 999 years from the date of the auction at the yearly rent calculated in accordance with the accepted bidding for the plot.

facts.text: Sitaram Luxman erected New Sitaram Building on the plots.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this agreement the said Sitaram Luxman erected those plots a building which has since companye to be known as the New Sitaram Building.

facts.text: Indentured lease dated April 19, 1916 between Trustees and Rustomji Dhunjibhoy Sethna (receiver of Sitaram Luxman in Suit No. 720 of 1913).

anchor.surface_text: the companypletion of the building, by an Indenture -of lease made April 19, 1916, between, the Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay and one Rustomji Dhunjibhoy Sethna the receiver of the estate of Sitaram Luxman appointed by the High Court in Suit No. 720 of 1913, the Trustees, pursuant to the said agreement and in companysideration of the monies which had been expended in the erection of the buildings and of the rent and the companyenants thereinafter reserved and companytained, demised unto the lessee all that piece of land situate their Princess Street estate together with the buildings erected thereon to hold the same for 999 years from April 15, 1908,

facts.text: Lease for 999 years from April 15, 1908, rent Re. 1 up to January 15, 1909, then Rs. 2,916 yearly.

anchor.surface_text: paying therefor up to January, 15, 1909, the rent of Re. I and during the remainder of the term the yearly rent of Rs. 2,916 by equal quarterly payments.

facts.text: Lessee covenanted to pay rates/taxes, restrictions on use, repairs, insure, etc.

anchor.surface_text: By the said Indenture the lessee companyenanted to pay all rates and taxes, number to use or to permit to be used, without the lessors companysent, the portion of land number built upon except as open space, number to pull down, add to or alter the buildings without such companysent, to keep in repair all drains sewers etc., to repair, pave, cleanse and paint and amend all the buildings, walls etc., to permit the lessors and their employees to enter upon the premises to inspect the companyditions thereof 48 hours numberice, to use the demised premises for residential purposes or as offices and schools only and number as a public house or liquor shop or for any business or trade, throughout the term to keep the buildings insured against fire in the joint names of the lessor and the lessee and to rebuild or reinstate and repair the building if destroyed or damaged by fire or otherwise.

facts.text: In 1925, properties of Trustees vested in Bombay Municipality by Bombay Act XVI of 1925.

anchor.surface_text: In 1925 all the properties of the Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay vested in the Bombay Municipality under and by virtue of Bombay Act XVI of 1925.

facts.text: Deed of assignment April 26, 1948, Shri Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Limited acquired lessee's interest.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed of assignment made April 26, 1948, Shri Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Limited, a society registered under the Bombay Co-operative Societies Act, VII of 1921, the appellant before us, acquired the lessees interest in the demised premises.

facts.text: June 29, 1948, appellant served notice to respondent, monthly tenant of Block No. B/2 ground floor at Rs. 52-5-9 monthly, to vacate by July 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: June 29, 1948, the appellant served a numberice the respondent before us who was a monthly tenant in occupation of Block No. B/2 the ground floor of the New Sitaram Building at a monthly rental of Rs. 52-5-9 to quit and vacate the same July 31, 1948.

facts.text: Respondent claimed protection of Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 (Act LVII of 1947).

anchor.surface_text: By his advocates reply the respondent maintained that he had been paying the rent regularly and otherwise performing the terms of his tenancy and claimed the protection of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947  Act LVII of 1947  The respondent number having vacated the block under his occupation the expiry of the numberice to quit,

facts.text: Appellant filed summary Suit No. 106 of 1948 in City Civil Court for possession of Block B/2 and mesne profits from August 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant filed summary Suit No. 106 of 1948 against the respondent in the City Civil Court at Bombay for vacant possession of the said Block No. B/2 the ground floor of the said New Sitaram Buildings and mesne profits from August 1, 1948, until delivery of possession.

facts.text: City Civil Court decreed suit in favour of appellant on January 24, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The learned City Civil Court Judge in a well-considered and careful judgment answered the issues in favour of the appellant and decreed the suit.

facts.text: Bombay High Court reversed, held Act applies, no jurisdiction, return plaint.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reversed the decision of the trial Judge and holding that the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 did apply to the premises and companysequently that the City Civil Court, by virtue of section 28 of that Act, had numberjurisdiction to entertain the suit, directed that the plaint, be returned to the appellant for being filed in the proper Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having declined to grant leave to the appellant to appeal to this Court, the appellant applied for and obtained special leave of this Court to prefer this appeal and filed this appeal pursuant to such leave.

facts.text: Premises belong to local authority (Bombay Municipality).

anchor.surface_text: In our view in the case before us the demised premises including the building belong to a local authority and are outside the operation of the Act.

The solution of that controversy depends upon a true construction of section 4 (1) of the Bombay Act LVII of 1947, Which runs as follows- 4. (1) This Act shall number apply to any premises belonging to the Government or a local authority or apply as against the Government to any tenancy or other like relationship created by a grant from the Government in respect of premises,taken lease or requisitioned by the Government but it shall apply in respect of premises let to the Government or a local authority.

concepts.interpretation: Exempts premises belonging to Government or local authority from the Act entirely, including as between lessee and sub-tenant, to protect interests of Government/local authority and facilitate development via building leases.
concepts.unlisted_label: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 Section 4(1)
concepts.unlisted_description: Exemption clause for premises owned by Government or local authority

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent took a preliminary objection, founded the provisions of section 28 of the Bombay Act, that the City Civil Court had numberjurisdiction to entertain the suit, for that section clearly states that in Greater Bombay the Court of Small Causes alone shall have jurisdiction

concepts.interpretation: Strips jurisdiction from City Civil Court if Act applies, vesting exclusive jurisdiction in Small Causes Court for rent/possession suits; inapplicable if Act does not apply to premises.

concepts.unlisted_label: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 Section 28
concepts.unlisted_description: Jurisdictional bar for suits relating to controlled premises

anchor.surface_text: then it must follow that under section 15 of the Act it will number be lawful for the lessee to sublet the premises or any part of it.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits subletting if Act applies, which would render building leases from Government/local authority impractical.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal filed with the special leave of this Court. It is directed against the judgment and decree passed December 2, 1949, by a Division Bench Weston and Shah JJ. of the Bombay High Court

Under section 105 of the Transfer of Property Act a lease is a transfer only of a right to enjoy the demised, premises, but there is numbertransfer of ownership or interest in the demised promises to the lessee such as there is in a sale section 54 or a mortgage section 58

concepts.interpretation: Defines lease as transfer of right to enjoy, not ownership; lessor retains ownership despite lessee's rights.

anchor.surface_text: The law of fixtures under section 108 of the Transfer of Property Act may be different from the English law, but section 108 is subject to any agreement that the parties may choose to make.

concepts.interpretation: Lessee's rights subject to agreement; building became lessor's property by agreement.

issues.text: whether the City Civil Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent took a preliminary objection, founded the provisions of section 28 of the Bombay Act, that the City Civil Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the suit, for that section clearly states that in Greater Bombay the Court of Small Causes alone shall have jurisdiction

issues.text: whether, in view of section 4 of the Act, the Act applies to the premises at all

anchor.surface_text: The crucial point, therefore, in order to determine the question of the jurisdiction of the City Civil Court to entertain the suit, is to ascertain whether, in view of section 4 of the Act, the Act applies to the premises at all. If it does, the City Civil Court has no jurisdiction

issues.text: who is to decide this point in controversy

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that a Civil Court has inherent power to decide the question of its own jurisdiction, although, as a result of its enquiry, it may turn out that it has no jurisdiction over the suit.

holdings.text: A Civil Court has inherent power to decide the question of its own jurisdiction, although as a result of its enquiry it may turn out that it has no jurisdiction over the suit.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that a Civil Court has inherent power to decide the question of its own jurisdiction, although, as a result of its enquiry, it may turn out that it has no jurisdiction over the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled law that civil courts determine applicability of jurisdictional bars like rent acts.

holdings.text: The preliminary objection that City Civil Court had no jurisdiction under section 28 of the Bombay Rents Act is not well founded and is rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we think, in agreement with the High Court, that this preliminary objection is not well founded in principle or authority and should be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction turns on whether Act applies, which civil court decides; if Act inapplicable, s28 cannot oust jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The first part of section 4(1) exempts premises belonging to the Government or a local authority entirely from the operation of the Act, without reference to tenancy relationships.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal construction distinguishes wording of first part (exempts premises) from second (exempts relationships as against govt); legislature deliberately omitted tenancy reference.

holdings.text: The immunity under first part of section 4(1) attaches to the premises themselves and is available to lessees deriving title from govt/local authority, not limited to govt/local as landlord.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate omission of 'as against govt/local'; limiting to direct landlord would make immunity illusory due to s15 subletting ban, frustrating building leases purpose.

holdings.text: The Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay and the Bombay Municipality are local authorities.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted as fact; vesting under Bombay Act XVI of 1925 confirms municipality as successor owner.

holdings.text: The demised premises including the building thereon belong to the local authority (Bombay Municipality as successor to Trustees).

anchor.surface_text: In our view in the case before us the demised premises including the building belong to a local authority and are outside the operation of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease under TP Act s105 transfers only right to enjoy, not ownership; covenants reserve lessor control over use, repairs, insurance; building erected for lessor vests in lessor per agreement overriding s108.

holdings.text: The Bombay Rents Act LVII of 1947 does not apply to the premises in suit.

anchor.surface_text: The main controversy between the parties is as to whether the Act applies to the demised premises. The solution of that controversy depends upon a true construction of section 4 (1) of the Bombay Act LVII of 1947,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Premises belong to local authority; entirely exempted by s4(1) first part as construed.

precedents.cited_proposition: words 'Property' and 'belonging to' are not technical words and are to be understood in their ordinary signification; they are convertible terms
precedents.cited_holding: 'The words Property and belonging to are number technical words in the law of Scotland. They are to be understood, I think, in their ordinary signification. They are infact companyvertible terms [...] What belongs to him is his pro- perty.'
